text:
Carrier Delivers an Efficiency Boost
Carrier offers several indoor units designed to deliver a boost to your cooling system
efficiency. Our variable-speed, Infinity® gas furnaces and fan coils deliver premium
comfort and humidity control in addition to even higher cooling SEER or SEER2. By
adding innovation to your home comfort system, you can enjoy enhanced comfort
throughout the seasons while achieving higher energy efficiency, potential cost savings WHAT’S IN AN
and possibly qualify for ENERGY STAR® designation as well.
ENERGYGUIDE LABEL?
Turn to the Experts
When you turn to Carrier for an efficiency boost, you are also securing the professional
advice, installation and maintenance from the true experts in home comfort – your local
Carrier dealer. Your Carrier dealer will work with you to help determine which system
best fits your needs. Once your system is installed, you can relax and enjoy the comfort
knowing your system is backed by Carrier, a leader in home comfort innovation.

What’s in a SEER or SEER2?
Efficiency Rating (SEER)*
15.0
SEER stands for Seasonal Energy Efficiency Ratio. It’s the industry standard for rating
the cooling efficiency of air conditioners and heat pumps. Much like miles-per-gallon for 13.4 19.0 F p o ro r d en u e c r t g in y f c o o . s e t n i e nf r o g , y v . i g s o it v
Least Efficient Most Efficient
a car, it’s an easy way to compare efficiencies of different products – the higher the SEER, Range of Similar Models
* Seasonal Energy Efficiency Ratio
the more efficient the unit. Once an air conditioner is installed, the SEER rating should be
easy to locate, displayed on the bright yellow EnergyGuide label.

Understanding the EnergyGuide Label Central Air Conditioner XYZ Corporation
Cooling Only Model NH65
Split System
Every home comfort product is required by the federal government to display the Efficiency Rating (SEER2)*
14.3
EnergyGuide label to help consumers make informed decisions about energy conservation
and efficiency of home comfort products. To make EnergyGuide an accurate comparison For energy cost info, visit
13.4 19.0 productinfo.energy.gov
tool, federal law requires all HVAC manufacturers to follow the same efficiency testing Least Efficient Most Efficient

procedures. For air conditioners, that test must be run using “the most common coil” sold * Seasonal Energy Efficiency Ratio 2
with the model as well as with a standard indoor heating unit. If a different coil or indoor
heating unit is installed as a part of your home comfort system, the SEER or SEER2 for Notice
